query: I'm 16 and help care for my mother who has MS in kent. This is affecting my schoolwork. Is there any support for young carers?

The council works with various carer support organisations who can offer help, advice, training, and support to carers, including balancing work and caregiving and has recently worked in partnership with neighbouring council colleagues to run a Kent and Medway initiative aimed at raising awareness of the support available for carers across the county with people being advised to seek advice and request a Carers Assessment from their local council. If you're not sure if you can get help as a caregiver, you can request a Carers Assessment. Visit support for carers on the Kent County Council website for more information or contact your local carer support organisation (Involve covers west Kent, Imago covers north Kent and Carers Support East Kent covers the east of the county). Kent County Council (KCC) has a responsibility to support people with 
specific needs to live independent and fulfilled lives safely in their local
community. We do this by providing information, advice and guidance 
as well as support and services.
We offer support to the following groups of people who are over 18:  
 yPeople with physical disabilities
 yPeople with sensory disabilities
 yPeople with learning disabilities
 yOlder people
 yPeople experiencing mental ill-health
 yPeople with autistic spectrum conditions
 yPeople who provide care and support to friends or family
 yPeople supported by Children’s Social Services who are

As a young carer in Kent, you can access support through **Kent Young Carers**, which provides carers aged 5-18 with information, advice, support, and social activities. This support can help you manage your schoolwork alongside your caring responsibilities.

**Details:**
- **Kent Young Carers** offers a range of short-term interventions, including signposting, one-to-one support, in-school support, and workshops. This can be particularly beneficial in addressing the impact of your caring role on your education.
- You can request a **Carers Assessment** to determine what additional support you might be eligible for. This assessment can help identify resources and services that can assist you in your role.

**Next Steps:**
- Visit the [Kent County Council website](https://www.kent.gov.uk/social-care-and-health/adult-social-care/care-and-support/caring-for-other-people) for more information on how to access these services.
- Consider contacting local carer support organizations such as Involve, Imago, or Carers Support East Kent, depending on your location within Kent, for further assistance and guidance.

By reaching out to these resources, you can find the support you need to balance your responsibilities as a young carer with your educational commitments.
